title: 105_s2433
content: TITLE X--FINANCIAL INFORMATION PRIVACY PROTECTION is added to the Consumer Credit Protection Act to enhance financial information privacy. The Financial Information Privacy Act, under Title X of the Consumer Credit Protection Act, includes sections on short title, definitions, privacy protection for customer information, enforcement, civil liability, criminal penalty, relation to State laws, and agency guidance. The Act defines terms like 'customer' and 'customer information of a financial institution'. The term 'customer information of a financial institution' refers to any information held by a financial institution related to its relationship with a customer, identified with the customer. The term 'financial institution' includes any institution providing financial services to customers with credit, deposit, trust, or other financial accounts. The Federal Reserve Act defines a financial institution as any depository institution, loan or finance company, credit card issuer, or consumer reporting agency. The Board of Governors may further define this term. Privacy protection for customer information of financial institutions prohibits obtaining customer information by false pretenses. Violation of privacy protection for customer information of financial institutions includes obtaining such information through false pretenses, such as making false statements to deceive officers, employees, or customers into releasing the information. The prohibition on solicitation of customer information from financial institutions under false pretenses includes knowingly providing forged documents to deceive officers into releasing the information. The section prohibits the solicitation of customer information from financial institutions under false pretenses. It does not apply to law enforcement agencies obtaining customer information for official duties or financial institutions testing security procedures or investigating misconduct. The section prohibits obtaining customer information from financial institutions under false pretenses, investigating misconduct, or recovering customer information. Enforcement is done by the Federal Trade Commission. Enforcement of compliance with the title is carried out by the Federal Trade Commission and other agencies such as the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency under specific circumstances. Enforcement of compliance with the title is carried out by the Federal Trade Commission and other agencies, including the Board, the Board of Directors of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and savings associations. Enforcement of compliance with the title is carried out by various agencies, including the Federal Trade Commission, the Board of Directors of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and savings associations. Violations of this title are treated as violations of other laws by relevant agencies. Each agency mentioned in paragraph (1) has the authority to enforce compliance with the title. States can also take action for violations, including bringing injunction actions in federal court and recovering damages on behalf of residents. The State can recover damages up to $1,000 for each violation, and in successful actions, they can also receive costs and attorney fees. Prior notice must be given to federal regulators before taking any action. The State can recover damages up to $1,000 for each violation and receive costs and attorney fees in successful actions. Prior notice must be given to federal regulators before taking any action. The Federal Trade Commission or an agency described in subsection (b) has the right to intervene, be heard on all matters, remove the action to the appropriate court, and file petitions for appeal in actions under this subsection. Investigatory powers are granted for bringing any action under this subsection. The chief law enforcement officer or designated state official can still conduct investigations and compel witnesses under this subsection. If a federal civil action is ongoing, no state can bring a separate action against the same defendant. "Any person failing to comply with this title regarding a financial institution or customer information shall be liable for actual damages sustained by the institution or customer, plus any amount received by the non-compliant person." Sec. 1006. Criminal penalty states that whoever violates section 1003 may face fines or imprisonment for up to 5 years. Enhanced penalties apply for aggravated cases involving other illegal activities. Sec. 1007. Relation to State laws states that this title does not override State laws unless they are inconsistent with it, providing greater protection under State law if it does not conflict with this title. Sec. 1008 requires Federal banking agencies to issue advisories to depository institutions to prevent prohibited activities. The Comptroller General must report to Congress on the effectiveness of the remedies provided in the amendments within 18 months of the enactment of this Act. The amendments address attempts to obtain financial information by fraudulent means or false pretenses and recommend additional legislative or regulatory action to protect financial privacy.
